title: Understanding the Ottoman State as a Dynastic Enterprise - Personal networks, family relations and the dynamics of power at the Ottoman Court
abstractText: Already in the early sixteenth century, when it was unequivocally still in its heyday, the Ottoman empire was being treated more as an abstraction than as a reality. Renaissance Italian thinkers in particular began to portray the Ottoman state as a faceless, featureless and essentially timeless set of institutions in which human agency played a minimal role. The proposed study intends to restore the human face to the Ottoman polity by examining the ways that family and personal networks (both dyanstic and province-centred) influenced the distribution and sharing power in the Ottoman state.
